The "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" establishes the Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program, defining key terms like "Pacific Ocean drainage area" and "Secretary." The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is established within the Department of the Interior to decrease fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems. Projects will be developed to mitigate impacts on fisheries caused by water diversions in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program aims to reduce fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. Projects will be implemented to mitigate impacts from water diversions by local governmental entities, focusing on developing fish screens, fish passage devices, and other related features. Priority will be given to projects costing less than $5,000,000. Non-Federal participation in the Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is voluntary. The Secretary will not hold non-Federal entities financially responsible unless they choose to participate. Projects on U.S. owned land will not require reimbursement. Evaluation and prioritization of projects will focus on those costing less than $5,000,000. Evaluation and prioritization of projects for development under the Program will be based on benefits to native fish species, size and type of water diversion, availability of funding sources, cost effectiveness, and additional opportunities for biological or water delivery system benefits. Eligibility requirements will also be considered. Eligibility requirements for projects under the Program include meeting Secretary and State requirements, agreement by all involved entities, consultation with various agencies, and use of available data. The non-Federal share of the cost for projects under the Program on non-Federal land or facilities is 35 percent. Non-Federal participants must provide necessary land, easements, and other resources for the project, which will be credited towards their share of the costs. Non-Federal responsibilities for projects on non-Federal land or facilities must be fulfilled. Under the Program, non-Federal participants must cover costs for projects on non-Federal land, while the Federal Government is responsible for costs on Federal land or facilities. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING. Projects funded under this Act cannot receive Federal funds from other sources for the same purpose.

SEC. 9. REPORT. After three fiscal years, the Secretary must report to Congress on completed projects, those to be completed in future fiscal years, and recommended Program changes based on project outcomes.

SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization for funding under this Act. Authorization of appropriations for this Act allows for $25,000,000 to be appropriated annually from 2001 to 2005. Limitations include not more than 25% of funds for projects in a single state, with a waiver option if the full amount cannot be utilized.
